title: 105_hr1124
content: Section 1 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a 100 percent capital gains deduction under Section 1201. The text chunk discusses the deduction of net capital gains for taxpayers, estates, and trusts, with coordination with the treatment of capital gain under the limitation on investment interest. Transitional rules are also mentioned for taxable years. Transitional rules apply for taxable years including January 1, 1997, limiting net capital gains to gains and losses after that date. Pass-thru entities have special rules for this determination. The determination of gains and losses for pass-thru entities is made at the entity level. Pass-thru entities include regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. A new deduction for long-term capital gains is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Technical and Conforming Changes are made to various sections of the tax code, including striking subsections and amending paragraphs. The deduction for long-term capital gains is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. The taxpayer sold the contributed property at fair market value. Section 172(d)(2) limits deductions for capital losses to gains. Section 453A(c)(3) amends the deduction for long-term capital gains. The tax code amendments include changes to deductions for long-term capital gains and adjustments for capital assets held for more than 1 year. The tax code amendments include changes to deductions for long-term capital gains for assets held over 1 year, with adjustments made for any allowable deductions under section 1201. Trust deductions are subject to unrelated business income rules, and certain sections specify that the capital gains deduction should not be taken into account. The tax code amendments involve repealing certain paragraphs and amending others related to deductions for long-term capital gains. The tax code is being amended to exclude the net capital gain from certain deductions related to long-term capital gains. The tax code amendments include changes to sections 871(a)(2), 882(a)(1), and 904(b)(2) of the Code, focusing on capital gains and foreign source income. The tax code amendments involve repealing section 1202, amending sections 1374 and 1381, and making changes to section 1402(i) and 1445(e) of the Code. The tax code is amended by changing specified rates and removing references to section 1201(a) in various clauses. Additionally, the imposition of tax on nonqualified withdrawals and capital gains is clarified. The Merchant Marine Act, 1936, is amended to exempt nonqualified withdrawals from capital gain accounts from taxation. The amendments made by section 1201 regarding capital gains deduction have specific effective dates for different provisions, ranging from taxable years ending after December 31, 1996, to contributions on or after January 1, 1997. Section 1122(h) of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is excluded when applying section 1201 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
